awd_titl_txt: REU Site:   Undergraduate Research Program in Genomics, Proteomics and Bioinformtics
awd_abstract_narration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to Florida A&M University that will provide research training for 8 students for 10 weeks, during the summers of 2012-2015. This program focuses on the use of basic tools in genomics, proteomics and bioinformatics to address important biological questions.  A multidisciplinary team of faculty from the disciplines of biology, agricultural sciences, and chemistry will serve as mentors. REU students will conduct full time lab research, as well as participate in seminars and workshops on topics like the responsible conduct of research, professional development, career opportunities, and the graduate school application process.  The program also includes visits to the University of Florida core facility and others to broaden student's exposure to cutting-edge instrumentation and techniques. Example projects include the genetic engineering of plants to impart resistance to abiotic and biotic stresses, the molecular and cellular studies to understand plant defense mechanism against attack by pathogens, using proteomics to elucidate protein functions, the study of gene expression in plant development, and others. Recruitment of students will utilize "hard copy" as well as digital-based advertising. Students will be selected based on their academic record, faculty recommendations, and research interest. Students will be tracked to determine their continued interest in their area of study, their career paths, and the lasting influence of the research experience. The program will be evaluated using the REU common assessment tool found at www.bioreu.org. More information can be found by visiting http://www.famu.edu/index.cfm?REU, or by contacting the PI, Dr. Virginia Gottschalk (virginia.gottschalk@famu.edu, 850-561-2750) or the co-PI, Dr. Ramesh Katam (ramesh.katam@gmail.com, 850-559-3134).

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
In our past REU, we have trained 25 undergraduate students in the functional biology research, 13 of whom are now enrolled in graduate programs in STEM disciplines, achieving the significant success rate of the program’s objective.   In addition, in our program trained 6 high school students recruited under the RAHSS program, with the majority of our REU and RAHSS students coming from under-represented minorities in STEM as documented below:

 

Demographic Make-up of Participants

Demographics

   Male  

 Female

  African Americans

3

9, 3*

  Native Americans

0

1

  Hispanic

1

2

  Asians

2, 1*

4, 2*

  White

1

2

 

 

 

 

 

 

 * = High School Students

 

SIGNIFICANT OUTCOMES 

1. Four manuscripts resulting from our students’ research have been published in peer-reviewed journals.

2. Our students’ research was presented at over 15 conferences, both national and international (sample below).

 

List of Peer-reviewed Publications and Sample of Conference Abstracts/Presentations Resulting From Research Done by FAMU-NSF REU and RAHSS Students (Students’ names in bold) 

Publications

  1. Ramesh Katam,  Kundai Chibanguza, Lekan M Latinwo and Danyl Smith. (2015) Proteome Biomarkers in Xylem Reveal Pierce’s Disease Tolerance in Grape. J Proteomics Bioinform 8:217-224. 
  2. Keyura Katam, Khoranhlai Anjuli Jones and Katsumi Sakata.  (2015) Advances in Proteomics and Bioinformatics in Agriculture Research and Crop Improvement. J Proteomics Bioinform 8:039-048. doi: 10.4172/jpb.1000351
  3. Ramesh Katam, Virginia Gottschalk, Prashanth Survajahala, George Brewster, Payton Paxton, Katsumi Sakata, Ching Lee*, Crayger Williams*, Baozhu Guo and Lekan M Latinwo. P 161-177, 2014. In: Genetics, Genomics ad Breeding of Peanuts. Eds: N. Mallikarjun and R. Varshney CRC Press, Science Publishers, Boca Raton
  4. Ramesh Katam, Jessica Saurez*, Shericka Williams*, Frank B Matta and Virginia Gottschalk.   Biochemical and molecular responses to water stress in grape. 126: 8-13, 2013 In: Proceedings of Florida State Horticulture Society, 2013.

 

Conferences/Published Abstracts

2015

  1. Sydney Lyda*, Ramesh Katam. Characterization of Xylem Sap Components Associated with Pierce’s Disease Tolerance, Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in STEM, February 28 - March 2, 2015: Washington DC, Recipient of ERN Travel Award)
  2. Longo, L.M., Tenorio, C.A*., Kumru, O.S., Middaugh, C.R., Blaber, M., A Single Aromatic Core Mutation Converts a Designed ‘Primitive’ Protein From Halophile to Mesophile Folding. The 29th Annual Symposium of The Protein Society, Barcelona, Spain (2015)
  3. Juan M. Gonzalez*, Ramesh Katam Muscadine Grape Leaf Proteomic Analysis, Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in STEM, February 28 - March 2, 2015: Washington DC

 

2014

  1. Ramesh Katam, Devaiah Kambrinda, Kentarou Ishige*, Katsumi Sakata, Tiratha Raj Singh, Vanamrung Isaragumpot*, Mayara de Souza Silva*. Interaction Studies of Differentially Expressed Proteins during Berry Development in Muscadine Grape. The 37th Annual meeting of the Molecular Biology Society of Japan, November 25-27, 2014.
  2. Ramesh Katam, Katsumi Sakata, Jeffri-Noelle Mays*, Mayara de Souza Silva, Karamthot Sivasankar Naik Analysis of Differentially Expressed Leaf Proteins and their Interaction in Response to Water Stress in Peanut 7th International Conference on Advances in Arachis through Genomics & Biotechnology, Savannah GA Nov 11-14, 2014.
  3. Ramesh Katam, Raja Reddy Kambham, Shardendu K Singh, Nitya S Murty* Analysis of Leaf Proteome to Determine Possible Cross-Tolerance to Abiotic Stresses in Soybean Cultivars. 25thInternational conference on Arabidopsis research, Vancouver, Canada, July 28-Aug1, 2014.
  4. Nitya Murthy*, Ramesh Katam, Differential Expression of Proteins to Abiotic Stresses in Soybean, 2014 Emerging Researchers National Conference, Washington DC, February 2014.

 

2013

  1. David Lindsey* et al Anion Directed Assembly of a Non-interpenetrated Square-Grid Metal Organic Framework with Nano-scale Porosity, Conference of Research Experiences for Undergraduates Student Scholarship, Arlington, VA 2013.
  2. Caryger Williams, Ramesh Katam, Prashanth Suravajhala, Ching Lee*, and Lekan M. Latinwo. Protein-protein interactions among water stress responsive proteins in peanut leaf. 17th Biennial Research Symposium of Association of Research Directors Inc., April 6-9, 2013.
  3. Kundai Chibanguza*, Devaiah M. Kambiranda, Ramesh Katam, Sheikh M. Basha, Lekan M. Latinwo. Identification of proteins associated with pierce’s disease tolerance in xylem tissue of Vitis species. 17th Biennial Research Symposium of Association of Research Directors Inc., April 6-9, 2013.
  4. Kundai Chibanguza*, Ramesh Katam, Kelechi Nwadigo. Proteome changes in xylem tissue in response to Pierce’s disease in Vitis species. 110th Annual Meeting of Southern Association of Agricultural Scientists. Orlando, FL February 2013.
  5. Shelletta C. Tilghman*, Ramesh Katam, Devaiah Kambiranda, and Sheikh M. Basha, Characterization of Xylem Sap Components Associated with Pierce’s Disease Tolerance, 2013 Emerging Researchers National Conference, Washington DC, February 2013.
  6. Ramesh Katam, Varshini Sridhar, Suneita Smith*, Pooja Chinthakuntla*, Lakshmi Badisa, Devaiah M Kambiranda, Musiliyu A Musa, Steve V Sluyter, Paul A Haynes, Virginia Gottschalk, Lekan M Latinwo, Mehboob B Sheikh, Grant R Cramer. Integrative metabolomics, proteomics approach to identify anticancer compounds in muscadine grape. Plant and Animal Genome, San Diego CA January 2013. P0875.

 

2012

  1. Kathryn I Vescio*, Devaiah Kambiranda, Mathew Reitzel, Shobha Devi Potlakayala: Proteome Profiles Of American Chestnut And Chinese Chestnut In Response To Salicylic Acid Chestnut Society 2102, American Chestnut Foundation Annual Summit: October 19-21, 2012, Asheville, NC

Modified by: Virginia Gottschalk
